translated: Birth Stories
The Fives🔽The Chapter with Short Stories
The Birth Story of Maṇikuṇḍala
“You’ve lost your chariot and your earrings,

original: Putte ca dāre ca tatheva jīno;
analyzed: putte ca dāre ca tathā iva jīno
translated: and your children and wife as well;
and all your possessions without exception.
Why aren’t you happy at the time of sorrow?”
“Wealth abandons the dead man first,
or the dead man abandons it first.
Wealth is impermanent, and so is the one who enjoys it.

original: Tasmā na socāmahaṁ sokakāle.🔽Udeti āpūrati veti cando,
analyzed: tasmai na socāmaham soka kāle  udeti āpūrati veti cando
translated: That’s why I don’t grieve at the time of sorrow.🔽The moon rises, fills up, and then disappears;
the sun shines, heats, and then sets.
I know the eight worldly conditions of the world.
That’s why I don’t grieve at the time of sorrow.”

analyzed: alasaḥ gihī kāma bhogī na sādhu
translated: “It’s not good for a householder to enjoy sensual pleasures;
it’s not good for one gone forth to be unrestrained.
It’s not good for a king to act without investigation;

original: Yo paṇḍito kodhano taṁ na sādhu.
analyzed: yaḥ paṇḍitaḥ kodhanaḥ tam na sādhu
translated: it’s not good for a wise person to be angry.
A noble should act with investigation,
not without investigation, lord of the earth.
For one who acts with investigation,
glory and praise increase.”
The Birth Story of Maṇikuṇḍala, the first.
